importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation, reflecting a significant public safety event in Israel.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the article's publication, indicating when the public was made aware of the match cancellation and unrest.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder.
Police reported 12 civilian injuries and 3 officer injuries, with 9 arrests and 16 people detained for questioning.
Footage showed fans throwing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, prompting authorities to cancel the match due to risk of human life endangerment.
Hapoel criticized the police response, claiming it appeared as if police were preparing for war rather than a sporting event.
The incident follows previous security concerns involving Maccabi fans in England and the Netherlands, where fan bans were imposed due to violent past behavior.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the ban on Maccabi fans in England, calling it wrong and emphasizing the need for inclusive football environments.
Downing Street stated it is working with Israeli authorities to understand the Tel Aviv incident and acknowledged concerns about violent behavior.
This event highlights tensions between public safety and fan freedom in international football, especially involving Jewish communities.

namedEntities.name: Ben Church

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two teams in the Tel Aviv derby, directly involved in the violent fan clashes and subsequent criticism of police actions.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi

namedEntities.name: Israel Police

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK police force that previously banned Maccabi fans from attending a match in England due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Host venue for a Europa League match where Maccabi fans were banned due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Ajax
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Team where Maccabi fans were involved in violent incidents last year, contributing to prior fan bans.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: UK leader who criticized the ban on Maccabi fans and acknowledged concerns about violence in Tel Aviv.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled on October 20, 2025, after police reported violent riots, including fans throwing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, resulting in 12 civilian injuries, 3 police injuries, 9 arrests, and 16 detentions. The Israeli police cited danger to human life as justification for the cancellation, but Hapoel criticized the response as overly aggressive and militarized. The incident follows prior security concerns involving Maccabi fans in England and the Netherlands, where fan bans were imposed due to past violent behavior. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the England ban, emphasizing fan safety and inclusivity, and stated the UK is collaborating with Israeli authorities to understand the Tel Aviv events.
title: Tel Aviv soccer derby canceled by police due to ‘violent riots’
